questions:
Based on the above premises, which statement can be inferred?
A. ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x))))
B. (((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x)))) ∧ ¬((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x)))))
C. ¬((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x))))
D. (((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x)))) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ((¬T(x) → ¬P(x)) → ForAll(x, Q(x)))))

Based on the above premises, is the statement true?
Statement: (¬T(x) → ¬P(x))
